prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC660 365 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
H2CO J=5-4 measurements toward NGC660.
Image at 0.2 arcsec spatial resolution with 5 km/s spectral channels.
Three spectral windows:
B7-365-1: 5(15)-4(14) at 351.768645 GHz
B7-365-2: 5(05)-4(04) at 362.736048 GHz 5(24)-4(23) at 363.945894 GHz 5(42)-4(41) at 364.103249 GHz 5(41)-4(40) at 364.103249 GHz
B7-365-3: 5(33)-4(32) at 364.275141 GHz 5(32)-4(31) at 364.288884 GHz 5(23)-4(22) at 365.363428 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To estimate the intensities of the proposed J=5-4 H2CO transitions towards NGC660 we consider the following:
-- The measured dense gas source size within the embedded starburst of NGC660 is <~ 4 arcsec based on our VLA 4.8 and 14.5 GHz H2CO measurements (Mangum etal 2015; Figure 2). NGC660 is a point source in Spitzer 24 micron measurements measured with 0.75 arcsec resolution (Brown etal 2014), suggesting that the source size is <~ 0.5 arcsec. Based on these measurements we assume a largest angular size of ~3 arcsec, with a likely dense gas source size of <~ 1 arcsec.
-- Figure 2 summarizes our GBT (theta_B = 51 and 153 arcsec) and VLA (theta_B = 4 arcsec) measurements of the H2CO absorption toward NGC660. All of these H2CO transitions have peak intensities of 1--2 mJy (2--4 mK; GBT) and 1--2 mJy (3--5 K; VLA).
-- Mangum etal (2013a) derive (log(n(H2)), log(N(orth-H2CO)/Deltav)) =~ (5.0,12.0) for an NH3-derived TK =~ 150 K (Mangum etal 2013b).
-- Predicted intensities based on LVG modeling for the proposed transitions (i.e. the intensities used to produce Fig. 1) scaled to our interferometer (theta_B = 4 arcsec) measurements range from 10 to 100 K (all in emission).
-- FWZI for most molecular line measurements of NGC660, including our H2CO measurements, is ~200 (NH3) to 1000 (H2CO) km/s. We assume that our high-excitation, high critical density H2CO measurements will possess an average linewidth of ~500 km/s.
Taking these factors into account we conservatively predict peak H2CO line intensities of at least 10 K (=~ 40 mJy at 365 GHz). As 10:1 signal-to-noise results in a time request that is almost completely dominated by overhead, we request a sensitivity limit of 0.5 K (2 mJy at 365 GHz) at the expense of an additional 10 minutes of on-source integration time.
NOTE: The high dynamic range warning is based on the strong dust continuum flux of 1 Jy, which is secondary to our project. We will, though, use this strong continuum source as a self-calibration source and improve the dynamic range of both our spectral line and continuum measurements.

Our correlator configuration parameters have been designed for maximum line measurement efficiency:
(1) BW = 1875 MHz within each spectral window noted in Table 1. For each spectral window this bandwidth will allow us to measure all of the B7-365 transitions listed in Table 1.
(2) Channel spacing of ~5 km/s at Band 7 (after smoothing). This spectral resolution will allow us to resolve any potential narrower (FWZI =~ 200 km/s) substructure and sample the entire ~500 km/s molecular emission line width.
(3) B7-365-2 spectral window approaches the limits of bandwidth and line accessibility. Maximum line separation = 1367 MHz, which when allowance for line structure (~2 x 300 MHz) results in a total line "occupation" of <1967 MHz. This compares favourably to the 1875 MHz of available bandwidth.
Line Overlap Considerations
We have also chosen our spectral line configurations to minimize overlap by both nearby H2CO transitions and "interloper" molecular species. The following transitions will be at least partially (<~ FWHM) blended (see Table 1):
(1) The "twin" transition pairs 5(42)-4(41)/5(41)-4(40) and 5(33)-4(32)/5(32)-4(31). Both of these transition pairs have identical predicted intensities.
(2) 5(24)-4(23)/5(4)-4(4) are separated by 157 MHz, which is potentially a significant fraction of the predicted FWHM linewidth. As the 5(23)-4(22) transition is the spectral "twin" (equivalent predicted intensity) to the 5(24)-4(23) transition, we will apply the measured spectral characteristics of the unblended 5(23)-4(22) transition to the spectral deconvolution of the 5(24)-4(23) transition.
A search for potential "interloper" molecular species, where we take as an analog the dusty embedded starburst nucleus NGC4418 (Costagliola etal. 2015), has uncovered only a few possibilities which are in all but one case >~100 MHz away from any of our proposed H2CO transitions: HNC J=4-3 at 362630.303 MHz, CH3OH 7(-5,2)-8(-4,5) at 365474.759 MHz and HC3N 40-39 at 363785.397 MHz.

Molecular spectral line and dust continuum measurements suggest the following regarding the dense gas source size and structure in NGC660:
-- Our proposed observing setup will utilize theta_B = 0.2 arcsec at Band 7. Using our VLA 1(10)-1(11) and 2(11)-2(12) H2CO measurements (theta_B = 4 arcsec; Mangum etal 2015), where the dense gas absorption source is not resolved, we estimate that theta_{las} =~ 3.0 arcsec. These measurements will certainly sample all of the dense gas emission from the embedded starburst in NGC660.
-- NGC660 is a point source in Spitzer 24 micron measurements measured with 0.75 arcsec resolution (Brown etal 2014), suggesting that the source size is <~ 0.5 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC660 290 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
H2CO J=4-3 measurements toward NGC660.
Image at 0.2 arcsec spatial resolution with 5 km/s spectral channels.
Three spectral windows:
B7-290-1: 4(14)-3(13) at 281.526929 GHz
B7-290-2: 4(04)-3(03) at 290.623405 GHz 4(23)-3(22) at 291.237780 GHz 4(32)-3(31) at 291.380488 GHz 4(31)-3(30) at 291.384264 GHz
B7-290-3: 4(22)-3(21) at 291.948060 GHz 4(13)-3(12) at 300.836635 GHz (could not quite get this one)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To estimate the intensities of the proposed J=4-3 H2CO transitions towards NGC660 we consider the following:
-- The measured dense gas source size within the embedded starburst of NGC660 is <~ 4 arcsec based on our VLA 4.8 and 14.5 GHz H2CO measurements (Mangum etal 2015; Figure 2). NGC660 is a point source in Spitzer 24 micron measurements measured with 0.75 arcsec resolution (Brown etal 2014), suggesting that the source size is <~ 0.5 arcsec. Based on these measurements we assume a largest angular size of ~3 arcsec, with a likely dense gas source size of <~ 1 arcsec.
-- Figure 2 summarizes our GBT (theta_B = 51 and 153 arcsec) and VLA (theta_B = 4 arcsec) measurements of the H2CO absorption toward NGC660. All of these H2CO transitions have peak intensities of 1--2 mJy (2--4 mK; GBT) and 1--2 mJy (3--5 K; VLA).
-- Mangum etal (2013a) derive (log(n(H2)), log(N(orth-H2CO)/Deltav)) =~ (5.0,12.0) for an NH3-derived TK =~ 150 K (Mangum etal 2013b).
-- Predicted intensities based on LVG modeling for the proposed transitions (i.e. the intensities used to produce Fig. 1) scaled to our interferometer (theta_B = 4 arcsec) measurements range from 10 to 100 K (all in emission).
-- FWZI for most molecular line measurements of NGC660, including our H2CO measurements, is ~200 (NH3) to 1000 (H2CO) km/s. We assume that our high-excitation, high critical density H2CO measurements will possess an average linewidth of ~500 km/s.
Taking these factors into account we conservatively predict peak H2CO line intensities of at least 10 K (=~ 30 mJy at 290 GHz). As 10:1 signal-to-noise results in a time request that is almost completely dominated by overhead, we request a sensitivity limit of 0.5 K (1.2 mJy at 290 GHz) at the expense of an additional 10 minutes of on-source integration time.
NOTE: The high dynamic range warning is based on the strong dust continuum flux of 1 Jy, which is secondary to our project. We will, though, use this strong continuum source as a self-calibration source and improve the dynamic range of both our spectral line and continuum measurements.

Our correlator configuration parameters have been designed for maximum line measurement efficiency:
(1) BW = 1875 MHz within each spectral window noted in Table 1. For each spectral window this bandwidth will allow us to measure all of the B7-290 transitions listed in Table 1.
(2) Channel spacing of ~5 km/s at Band 7 (after smoothing). This spectral resolution will allow us to resolve any potential narrower (FWZI =~ 200 km/s) substructure and sample the entire ~500 km/s molecular emission line width.
(3) B7-290-2 spectral window approaches the limits of bandwidth and line accessibility. Maximum line separation = 761 MHz, which when allowance for line structure (~2 x 300 MHz) results in a total line "occupation" of <1361 MHz. This compares favourably to the 1875 MHz of available bandwidth.
Line Overlap Considerations
We have also chosen our spectral line configurations to minimize overlap by both nearby H2CO transitions and "interloper" molecular species. The following transitions will be at least partially (<~ FWHM) blended (see Table 1):
(1) The "twin" transition pairs 4(32)-3(31)/4(31)-3(30) are separated by 4 MHz. Both of these transition pairs have identical predicted intensities.
(2) 4(23)-3(22)/4(3)-3(3) transitions are separated by 143 MHz, which is potentially a significant fraction of the predicted FWHM linewidth. As the 4(23)-3(22) transition is the spectral "twin" (equivalent predicted intensity) to the 4(22)-3(21) transition, we will apply the measured spectral characteristics of the unblended 4(22)-3(21) transition to the spectral deconvolution of the 4(23)-3(22) transition.
A search for potential "interloper" molecular species, where we take as an analog the dusty embedded starburst nucleus NGC4418 (Costagliola etal. 2015) and use the Cycle 0 spectral scan, which includes the 290 GHz frequency range we propose to measure, has uncovered only two possibilities which are all >~100 MHz away from any of our proposed H2CO transitions: HC3N J=32-31 at 291068.43 MHz and CH3CCH J=17-16 (multiple transitions) in the range 289095.80 to 290502.05 MHz.

Molecular spectral line and dust continuum measurements suggest the following regarding the dense gas source size and structure in NGC660:
-- Our proposed observing setup will utilize theta_B = 0.2 arcsec at Band 7. Using our VLA 1(10)-1(11) and 2(11)-2(12) H2CO measurements (theta_B = 4 arcsec; Mangum etal 2015), where the dense gas absorption source is not resolved, we estimate that theta_{las} =~ 3.0 arcsec. These measurements will certainly sample all of the dense gas emission from the embedded starburst in NGC660.
-- NGC660 is a point source in Spitzer 24 micron measurements measured with 0.75 arcsec resolution (Brown etal 2014), suggesting that the source size is <~ 0.5 arcsec.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A characterization of the physical properties of the dense gas within the interstellar medium of starburst galaxies is critical to our understanding of their evolution. Many of the molecular tracers used to characterize the dense gas in star-forming galaxies suffer from a coupled degenerate sensitivity to the kinetic temperature and volume density. A molecular tracer which can decouple individual physical conditions is required. Results from a survey of a sample of active star-forming galaxies has shown that formaldehyde (H2CO) is a reliable and accurate density probe for extragalactic environments where the kinetic temperature is known. Ammonia (NH3) is a traditional probe of the kinetic temperature in dense gas environments, but its utility requires an assumption of cospatiality between dense gas tracers. Using the unique sensitivities to kinetic temperature and volume density afforded by the excitation characteristics of several transitions of H2CO, we propose to continue our characterization of the dense gas in galaxies exhibiting starbursts by imaging the gas kinetic temperature and volume density in the IR-bright polar ring galaxy NGC660.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Astrophysics and Space Astronomy, Colorado at Boulder, Univ of
